results.title: Art 4 Starts
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Sonya Waters and ACMI
results.brief_description: What other people consider vandalism or graffiti, Sonya Waters sees as street art. Behind the work, Waters recognises the skill and social commentary inherent in the work and seeks to help the artists, often kids from disadvantaged backgrounds, recognise the artistic and social value of their work and become empowered by it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Sonya Waters and ACMI

results.title: Unwise and foolish creations of fancy
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Sally McCutcheon and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sally McCutcheon tells her story, threaded together by her two life-long passions, dancing and beading. Through determination, discipline and the support of her family, McCutcheon has managed to excel at both at different stages of her life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Sally McCutcheon and ACMI

results.title: Princes Street Port Melbourne
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Lyn McLeavy and ACMI
results.brief_description: A tribute to a suburb, a family and a lady who liked to play the piano and sing the blues. Lyn McLeavey describes growing up in Port Melbourne in the 1950s, blending in the harsh realities of life as the daughter of a traumatised ‘wharfie’, with the simple joy of the sounds of the streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Lyn McLeavy and ACMI

results.title: Coming home
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Louise Blake and ACMI
results.brief_description: Despite being born in Canberra, Louise Blake’s family history has very strong ties to Melbourne. Over the years, family trips have drawn Blake ‘south of the border’, where suburbs like Port Melbourne and Brunswick evoke stories from her family history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Louise Blake and ACMI
results.description: Despite being born in Canberra, Louise Blake’s family history has very strong ties to Melbourne. Over the years, family trips have drawn Blake ‘south of the border’, where suburbs like Port Melbourne and Brunswick evoke stories from her family history.

results.title: I am safe
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Joyce Evans and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 2005, the Australian Federal Government introduced new laws to address to potential and perceived threat of terrorism. Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Joyce Evans and ACMI
results.description: In 2005, the Australian Federal Government introduced new laws to address to potential and perceived threat of terrorism. Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.
description_for_label: In 2005, the Australian Federal Government introduced new laws to address to potential and perceived threat of terrorism. Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.

results.title: The Port mob
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Edwin Whiting and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edwin Whiting speaks fondly of his time when he and his mates had the run of Port Melbourne in the 1930s. They spent most of their spare time together, but World War II changed everything.

results.title: Why plant millions of trees
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Alfred Zerfas and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alfred Zerfas gives background to and outlines the achievements of Social Education and Development Society (SEDS). This organisation was started in the 1980s in response to the crushing effects of drought in Southern India. With persistance over the decades, the work of SEDS, in collaboration with the communities they support, has brought about economic, social and enviromental change in these communities with lasting benefits.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Alfred Zerfas and ACMI

With persistance over the decades, the work of SEDS, in collaboration with the communities they support, has brought about economic, social and enviromental change in these communities with lasting benefits.

results.title: Listen up my cherubs!
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Karen Milward and ACMI
results.brief_description: Energetic and intelligent, Karen Milward is constantly engaged with life. Often on the road for her work in the Aboriginal community, her children wonder what it is she actually does. This story is by way of explanation and gives insight into the life of an amazing community worker and consultant.
